Family Business may be criticised for being another mindless "take that" game where bashing the leader is the best course of action. But it isn't. The optimal strategy is instead to always target the player on your right, since if your attack gets countered and your target becomes the active player, you're next in turn order. Which manages to make the experience even worse than the previous assumption!

Also, whoever was responsible for the 2000s French version, thought that a mafia mob war was not a suitable setting and concluded that the fantasy of commiting a genocide against fairytale species by chewing them alive would be more marketable should maybe question their sanity.

just a Take That game that usually ends up in bashing the leader. Theme is done quite well but that's about it.

Take-that made fun only through hard work

One play and I was knocked out pretty quick... I think they were after me . I did see that I mis-managed what I was doing a bit, but it was fun for a relatively quick little card game of "take that."

Played again and it's just "take that" which I won the second time. Unfortunately, it seems to have the common bash-the-leader feel and be lucky enough to draw the right cards to win. The theme and game play does cause a feeling of dread, but I'm not sure this is exactly my style of game.

This is an old-school version of Guillotine, with the primary difference being that it takes an initial threshold before the gangsters start getting killed and all the gangsters are the same; instead, you play action cards. It's not bad for occasional silly fun, but that's about it.

I liked it at first, but over time I'd rather play Mille Bornes for Take That and I'd rather play Guillotine for the "line up" feature, and I'd rather play "The Boss" for the mafia/crime theme. So after the first few plays, it just didn't scratch any of the itches better than the other games I mentioned above.
A game probably better with 3 or more players.

Based on one 4 player session; an interesting themed card game with player elimination, just nothing which demands that it be on the immediate replay list (14/12/08). UPDATE It's ok (Rating 5.758 Jan 17). UPDATE: One for the Board Game Event Horizon (Dec 19). UPDATE: Pub Meeple Ranking Engine Dec 2020 (Rating: 4.033).

A card based game where players are trying to be the last mobster standing (starting with 9). Players take a card, then play a card (usually adding player's mobsters into hit list). The hit list starts at the deck and expands. Once it hits 6 mobsters long (aka starts a mob war), each start of a turn, the first mobster in line is killed until all mobsters in the hit list is killed, ending mob war, until it mob war starts up again.
A fast paced game about mob war. Great stuff and nice graphics to boot.

Though the majority of this card game is rather simplistic - due to its heavy reliance on basic "luck of the draw" mechanics - the game is elevated somewhat in status over its card game brethren due to its rather interesting "Hit List" mechanic - cards are played in a line (called "the hit list") and the actual order of them is vastly important as it means life and death for your gang members. The cards can be altered, swapped out, and re-arranged depending upon the cards you have in your hand. This thankfully does add a much needed strategic element to the proceedings, which would have been rather bland otherwise.

Please note that the 2006 edition has a rather annoying attribute - action cards have only the titles printed on them with no directions or instructions whatsoever. In order to know what the ability of each card is, you will have to look in the instruction manual. This is acceptable for those who know the game well and have played it often, but is very frustrating when people are new to the game. Thankfully, this is corrected in the newest edition (2009).
